devdoc.details: This contract lays the foundation for transaction computations, including   bonding curve calculations and variable management. Version 0 of this contract   does not implement any transaction logic.

approve(address,uint256).details: See {IERC20-approve}. Requirements: - `spender` cannot be the zero address.

calculateBuyReturn(uint256).details: Function that computes number of product tokens one can buy given an amount in reserve token.

params._amountReserve: purchaing amount in reserve token (dai)(with 4% platform fee)

returns.mintAmount: number of tokens in traded token that can be purchased by given amount.

calculateSellReturn(uint32).details: Function that computes selling price in reserve tokens given an amount in traded token.

returns.soldAmount: total amount that will be transferred to the seller (with 2% platform fee).

decimals().details: Returns the number of decimals used to get its user representation. For example, if `decimals` equals `2`, a balance of `505` tokens should be displayed to a user as `5,05` (`505 / 10 ** 2`). Tokens usually opt for a value of 18, imitating the relationship between Ether and Wei. This is the value {ERC20} uses, unless this function is overloaded; NOTE: This information is only used for _display_ purposes: it in no way affects any of the arithmetic of the contract, including {IERC20-balanceOf} and {IERC20-transfer}.

decreaseAllowance(address,uint256).details: Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller. This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {IERC20-approve}. Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. Requirements: - `spender` cannot be the zero address. - `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least `subtractedValue`.

getAvailability().details: Function to check how many tokens of this product are currently available for purchase, by taking the difference between max cap count and current token in circulation or burned.

getCurrentPrice().details: Function that computes current price for a token through bonding curve calculation based on parameters such as total supply, reserve balance, and reserve ratio.

returns.price: current price in reserve token (in our case, this is dai). (with 4% platform fee)

getEscrowHistory(address).details: Return the list of all escrows created for a certain user

getPriceForN(uint32).details: Function that computes price total for buying n token through bonding curve calculation based on parameters such as total supply, reserve balance, and reserve ratio.

returns.price: total price in reserve token (in our case, this is dai). (with 4% platform fee)

getRedeemStatus(address,uint256).details: Get status of a particular redemption process

params._id: The cached id of the escrow, retrieved from database

increaseAllowance(address,uint256).details: Atomically increases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller. This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {IERC20-approve}. Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. Requirements: - `spender` cannot be the zero address.

params._baseReserve: the base amount of reserve tokens, in accordance to _supplyOffset.
params._maxTokenCount: the amount of token that will exist for this type.
params._reserveRatio: the reserve ratio in the curve function. Number in parts per million
params._supplyOffset: this amount is used to determine initial price.

isStateCompleted(uint8).details: Helper function to check whether a escrow state is completed

launch().details: requires function to be called from owner. this enables customers to buy, sell, or redeem the product.

name().details: Returns the name of the token.

owner().details: Returns the address of the current owner.

pause().details: requires function to be called from owner. this prevents customers from buying, selling, or redeeming the product.

renounceOwnership().details: Leaves the contract without owner. It will not be possible to call `onlyOwner` functions anymore. Can only be called by the current owner. NOTE: Renouncing ownership will leave the contract without an owner, thereby removing any functionality that is only available to the owner.

setBondingCurve(address).details: requires function to be called from owner. sets a bonding curve implementation for this product.

params._address: the address of the bonding curve implementation

symbol().details: Returns the symbol of the token, usually a shorter version of the name.

transfer(address,uint256).details: See {IERC20-transfer}. Requirements: - `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - the caller must have a balance of at least `amount`.

transferFrom(address,address,uint256).details: See {IERC20-transferFrom}. Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not required by the EIP. See the note at the beginning of {ERC20}. Requirements: - `sender` and `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`. - the caller must have allowance for ``sender``'s tokens of at least `amount`.

transferOwnership(address).details: Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`). Can only be called by the current owner.

updateUserCompleted(address,uint256).details: used to update the status of redemption to "User Complete" after an escrow process has been started.

params.buyer: the wallet address of product buyer
params.id: the id of the escrow, returned to the user after starting of redemption process

updateUserRefund(address,uint256).details: used to update the status of redemption to "User Refunded" after an escrow process has been started.

params.buyer: the wallet address of product buyer
params.id: the id of the escrow, returned to the user after starting of redemption process

devdoc.title: ProductToken

userdoc.notice: This is version 0 of the product token implementation.
